body:
I have read,
[https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/10983](url)
[https://superuser.com/questions/578065/powershell-very-slow-to-open-respond](url)
[https://stackoverflow.com/questions/59341482/powershell-steps-to-fix-slow-startup](url)
 but I didn't get help.
I have disabled the startup update detection, but the startup is still slow

I tried removing profile , but startup is still slow. At the same time, I'm doing a startup test in 7.3.0-preview.3 and the startup is equally slow.

It may be Telemetry trying to find its server in which case Setting the environment variable  `POWERSHELL_TELEMETRY_OPTOUT` to true, yes, or 1 might help

But I think this is checking to see if there is a new version, and if it can't contact the server there is a timeout issue. 

Paging @doctordns  - you've said you'd like PowerShell not to give the message about new versions when they are setup to come from WU and it doesn't have them yet,  should "no check for new versions at all"  be an option for (e.g.) servers which aren't allowed internet access.

Thanks for the page @jhoneill!

So on the day when 7.2.2 was released, as expected, I get the message that there is a new version. FIne, I thought, I KNOW I d setup MU to update it. But the error is not going away - I will need to wait a MONTH. My reaction is not positive. If an update is important enough for me to be notified, then we need to get the package to MU faster. I mean - how long would MSFT wait to fix CVE types bugs??   

And - unlike VSCode which can fix this issue, there is no ```Update-PowerShell``` cmdlet in the console. So either I just wait a month and get annoyed at each console I open - or I just go and run the update manually. Seems somewhat sub-optimal.ðŸ˜ŠAll in all, the message, for most users, is not actionable easily. 

There are several suggestions;
1. Ensure MU gets and pushes upgrades in less than a month. Seems to me that the update would be available on MU within 48 hours of it being on GitHub. That may need more work but it seems the best answer.
2. In the absence for a in-box ```Update-PowerShell``` cmdlet, PowerShell should not put the message out until the update is on MU. 
3. Perhaps give MU 2 weeks and only show the message after, say., 2 weeks.
4. Change the message to tell the user what to do -that is, give them a simple way to fix the issue. 
5. Create, as James suggests, environment variables to tell PowerShell what to do in the case a new version, if found. Your point about air-gapped servers is apt!

> It may be Telemetry trying to find its server in which case Setting the environment variable `POWERSHELL_TELEMETRY_OPTOUT` to true, yes, or 1 might help
> 
> But I think this is checking to see if there is a new version, and if it can't contact the server there is a timeout issue.
> 
> Paging @doctordns - you've said you'd like PowerShell not to give the message about new versions when they are setup to come from WU and it doesn't have them yet, should "no check for new versions at all" be an option for (e.g.) servers which aren't allowed internet access.

Thanks for your help, it looks like it's working now.

> 
> So on the day when 7.2.2 was released, as expected, I get the message that there is a new version. FIne, I thought, I KNOW I d setup MU to update it. But the error is not going away - I will need to wait a MONTH. My reaction is not positive. If an update is important enough for me to be notified, then we need to get the package to MU faster. I mean - how long would MSFT wait to fix CVE types bugs??
> 
> And - unlike VSCode which can fix this issue, there is no `Update-PowerShell` cmdlet in the console. So either I just wait a month and get annoyed at each console I open - or I just go and run the update manually. Seems somewhat sub-optimal.blushAll in all, the message, for most users, is not actionable easily.
> 
> There are several suggestions;
> 
> 1. Ensure MU gets and pushes upgrades in less than a month. Seems to me that the update would be available on MU within 48 hours of it being on GitHub. That may need more work but it seems the best answer.
> 2. In the absence for a in-box `Update-PowerShell` cmdlet, PowerShell should not put the message out until the update is on MU.
> 3. Perhaps give MU 2 weeks and only show the message after, say., 2 weeks.
> 4. Change the message to tell the user what to do -that is, give them a simple way to fix the issue.
> 5. Create, as James suggests, environment variables to tell PowerShell what to do in the case a new version, if found. Your point about air-gapped servers is apt!

I have manually updated to 7.2.5 and the problem reappeared. and I have set the relevant environment variables.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24800663/182303830-4152b608-4c50-4c54-b7e6-83e465d2dfea.png)

This is a historical issue. It looks like the same problem has existed since 2019.
> https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/10983

If anyone has the same problem, please refer to the link below. It solved my problem.
> https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/10983#issuecomment-779819256

> 

Now my startup time has changed from 5-10 seconds to 2-3 seconds.

> This is a historical issue. It looks like the same problem has existed since 2019.
> 
> > #10983
> 
> If anyone has the same problem, please refer to the link below. It solved my problem.
> 
> > [#10983 (comment)](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/10983#issuecomment-779819256)

Now my startup time has changed from 5-10 seconds to 2-3 seconds.
Doesn't look like the best result, but I've been able to live with it

Regarding the time it takes for MU to get and then deploy the updated version of PowerShell. At one time, it did seem to take a month. But, it is taking much less time, it seems to me, these days - down to 2 weeks (or IIRC less recently). You are right that the solution within VSCode is rather more user-friendly.  So it's not QUITE as bad as you suggest, but I do take the point that we can do this better.  Maybe we move to sim-shipping - that is, releasing on GitHub ONLY when the package is available at MU.  Not sure how practical that is, but as I say we can do better.

> This is a historical issue. It looks like the same problem has existed since 2019.
> 
> > #10983
> 
> If anyone has the same problem, please refer to the link below. It solved my problem.
> 
> > [#10983 (comment)](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/10983#issuecomment-779819256)

This may get better in 7.3  
If you look at at 7.2 there are a lot of different certs being used to sign modules and DLLs, and pwsh.exe. 

Try 
```
CD $PSHOME
dir -re *.ps*,*powershell*.dll,pwsh.exe  | Get-AuthenticodeSignature | sort @{e={$_.SignerCertificate.Thumbprint}},path |    ft @{n="Cert";e={$_.SignerCertificate.Thumbprint}}, path

```
Repeating it with 7.3 preview things seem to moving to using the same cert as pwsh.exe . 

**EDIT**  I think those modules which are built separately and then brought into the PowerShell distribution bundle _still_ select their cert independently, but PsReadline is now using the same cert as the rest of PowerShell.

> Regarding the time it takes for MU to get and then deploy the updated version of PowerShell. At one time, it did seem to take a month. But, it is taking much less time, it seems to me, these days - down to 2 weeks (or IIRC less recently). You are right that the solution within VSCode is rather more user-friendly. So it's not QUITE as bad as you suggest, but I do take the point that we can do this better. Maybe we move to sim-shipping - that is, releasing on GitHub ONLY when the package is available at MU. Not sure how practical that is, but as I say we can do better.

I don't think it's about the update, it's the fact that the checking of the system certificate in the absence of a network blocks the powershell thread, resulting in a slow startup.

> CD $PSHOME
> dir -re *.ps*,*powershell*.dll,pwsh.exe  | Get-AuthenticodeSignature | sort @{e={$_.SignerCertificate.Thumbprint}},path |    ft @{n="Cert";e={$_.SignerCertificate.Thumbprint}}, path
> ```
> 
> Repeating it with 7.3 preview things seem to moving to using the same cert as pwsh.exe .
> 
> **EDIT** I think those modules which are built separately and then brought into the PowerShell distribution bundle _still_ select their cert independently, but PsReadline is now using the same cert as the rest of PowerShell.

Actually, I'm using version 7.2.5 now and the problem persists.
Can you tell me how this workaround works?
